Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support for participants, especially women, graduate students, postdocs, and young faculty, in the "Oxtoby Centennial Conference" that will be held at Bryn Mawr College on October 30-31, 2010.

The purpose of this conference is to celebrate the legacy of John C. Oxtoby (1911-1991), a longtime faculty member at Bryn Mawr College and a driving force in the evolution of that institution's strong mathematics program. The focus of the conference is on the areas of ergodic theory and measure theory, in which Oxtoby was a figure of great influence by virtue of both his research contributions and his pioneering graduate text on measure theory. Both topics, but especially ergodic theory, remain central and extremely active subjects of current research. The format of the meeting is such that young people, including undergraduates, will have ample opportunities to speak and be otherwise engaged in the various conference activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported two conferences in Ergodic Theory and Dynamical Systems. The first one was a two-day conference that took place at Bryn Mawr College, Pennsylvania, in October 2010. The conference had talks addressed to mathematicians, some talks addressed to specialists in dynamical systems, and two talks addressed to the general public that were attended by a large number of undergraduate students. There was also a session of four talks by Ph.D. students. Participants learned about recent research in ergodic theory and dynamical systems, including the important work of Oxtoby and its developments. The website for the conference, including some pictures of the attendees is at

http://web.williams.edu/Mathematics/csilva/Oxtoby_Centennial_Conf.htm



The second conference was a two and a half day conference at Williams College, Massachusetts, that took place in July 2012. This was a conference in ergodic theory, with an emphasis on recent work in nonsingular and infinite measure-preserving dynamical systems. There were several international speakers, including speakers from France, Israel, Mexico, Poland, South Korea, and Ukraine that came to interact with the U.S. participants. There were also two undergraduate speakers who talked on their current research, with five additional undergraduate students who attended the talks. The conference also had three talks by Ph.D. students and two talks by recent Ph.D.s.  The website for the conference with a pictures of the attendees is at

http://web.williams.edu/Mathematics/csilva/Williams_ErgodicTheory2012.html
